cleaning: EXPLOITING ALPHA TRANSPARENCY IN LANGUAGE AND VISION- BASED AI SYSTEMS David Noever1 and Forrest McKee1 PeopleTec , 4901-D Corporate Drive , Huntsville , AL , USA , 35805 1david.noever @ peopletec.com 2 forrest.mckee @ peopletec.com ABSTRACT This investigation reveals a novel exploit derived from PNG image file formats , specifically their alpha transparency layer , and its potential to fool multiple AI vision systems . Our method uses this alpha layer as a clandestine channel invisible to human observers but fully actionable by AI image processors . The scope tested for the vulnerability spans representative vision systems from Apple , Microsoft , Google , Salesforce , Nvidia , and Facebook , highlighting the attack 's potential breadth . This vulnerability challenges the security protocols of existing and fielded vision systems , from medical imaging to autonomous driving technologies . Our experiments demonstrate that the affected systems , which rely on convolutional neural networks or the latest multimodal language models , can not quickly mitigate these vulnerabilities through simple patches or updates . Instead , they require retraining and architectural changes , indicating a persistent hole in multimodal technologies without some future adversarial hardening against such vision-language exploits . KEYWORDS Adversarial attacks , computer vision , transformers , AI safety , security exploit compromised successfully representative models 1 . INTRODUCTION In previous work [ 1 ] , we described a novel attack on vision-based systems such as object recognition , autonomous driving cameras , image-based datasets , and multimodal language models . Sixteen vision systems were [ 1 ] , including from Apple , Microsoft , Google , Salesforce , Nvidia , and Facebook . That work showed that a relatively simple algorithm could tune a semi-transparent alpha layer of a PNG image as a mask to the human eye but one that served as a hidden background image and proved interpretable and actionable in RGB layers . Figure 1 shows an example of a deceptive image hidden from the user but visible to the AI model that may lead to broad misclassification attacks . This new adversarial attack is built on a previous history of designer patterns fine-tuned to fool object detectors [ 2-8 ] . Our earlier findings investigated this effect as a different kind of digital watermark [ 9-13 ] , not to establish copyright but to confuse or fool vision-based decision-making . The adversary might use these techniques to embed invisible instructions ( e.g. , steganography [ 14-15 ] ) or poison other image training data with hidden and incorrect object labels [ 16-18 ] . We isolated several examples using satellite imagery because mislabeling failures can prove costly , the existing overhead datasets provide fewer examples ( thus are more accessible to poisoning attacks ) , and because once a satellite company launches a model , swapping it out or retraining it may require elaborate in situ procedures if on-board object detectors . Figure 1 . Deceptive Insertion of Alpha Layer to Poison Training or Inference Data for AI Classifiers of Human Activity We also illustrated some potential mitigation steps [ 19-30 ] , including training ( actually mis-training ) a classifier to recognize just the RGB background and ignore the semi-transparent foreground that a human labeler otherwise might tag . We extend this work to employ visual imagery as prompts for further AI actions . Examples of downstream consequences begin with style transfer models that , for instance , colorize the wrong layer that the human user requests or mislabel sentiment and mood sufficiently so that an attacker could alter a prompted storyline in ways invisible to the intended initial narrative request . We showed several contrasting examples of logo brands swapped or spam candidates that would lead to the misclassification of an attack icon in an email message . Figure 2 . The target image is an overhead satellite view of a freeway ( left ) , the attack image is a mushroom cloud ( center ) , and the Feb 2024 version of Google 's Gemini multi-modal labeler describes the hidden attack layer and ignores the satellite image ( right ) . We noted several limitations to this transparency attack , including the constraint that the transparent alpha layer and the RGB background roughly matched in light-dark tone as grayscale . A second shortcoming of fooling the human viewer depended on a light-themed application such as a browser or image editor . Under high contrast ( dark themes ) and lighter image stacks , the transparent layer revealed the RGB background . The application background does not affect the machine 's interpretation of the image but makes the human viewer see the underlying background through the semi-transparent cover layer . When first reported , our study demonstrated sixteen different vision systems succumbed to the adversarial attack , including GPT4-vision , stable diffusion generators ( Midjourney ) , object detectors ( YOLOv5 ) , and classifiers ( MobileNetv2 , Inception , GPT2 , and Blip image captioners ) . The model developers spanned the gamut from closed to open models from Microsoft , Apple , Salesforce , Facebook , and OpenAI . At the time , the attack proved less robust with the Bard multimodal models from Google , but as shown in Figure 2 with fine-tuning , the present work illustrates that the attack also covers that case . The target image is what the user or labeler sees , which is a freeway seen from a satellite overhead . The attack image is the RGB grayscale pixels of a mushroom cloud which is visible to the algorithm when it strips the alpha layer . Gemini responds with a caption describing the hidden image only and the satellite picture of the freeway gets misclassified as a nuclear explosion . This example highlights the potential for poisoning critical datasets . One apparent reason for the broad susceptibility involves flattening color imagery in RGB pixel space before training a convolutional neural network or transformer architecture . Adding a new alpha layer to that encoding proves expensive ( potentially unnecessarily ) and restricts the vision model to substitute a transparent layer when the image compression format lacks it , such as JPEG , TIFF , MP4 , etc . In other words , why treat the PNG alpha layer as something worth training on in the wild ? One plausible answer to this motivates the present work , that mainly the ignoring layer alpha opens a up vulnerable a to model series of stealthy attacks that extend the rails guard to required keep the AI models safe for public use . In this way , the corner case of image transparency opens gambit of previous text-based injection attacks but , in a way , is invisible to the model user and potentially to the model builder . While this explanation lends itself to understanding the origins of the flattened image modeling and its dismissal of transparency-embedded data , it also highlights how difficult a fix might prove . Removing the vulnerability would require retraining models and altering their 3-dimensional color pixel architectures as convolutional neural nets or large transformers . Furthermore , fine-tuning safe guardrails also requires additional work , just as others have noted that the English-only instructions for safety tend to fail in some more obscure languages or dialects . In our case , the alien language is integral to the pixels and layers . Figure 3 . The transparency attack provides misleading chart information to a machine compared to human vision in GPT4-Vision ( FEB 2024 ) , The target image is a stock chart trending up ( lower left ) , the attack image is a descending trend ( upper left ) , and the Feb 2024 version of GPT4-Vision multi-modal labeler describes the hidden attack layer and ignores what the human analyst sees as the strong upward trend ( right ) . the The primary impetus behind the present work stems from a need to understand the scope and breadth of the available attack surface and treat this new class of adversarial images in light of the rapid progress in powerful multimodal modeling from Open AI and Google . Unlike a task to make a model mislabel an image or respond to an image-text prompt outside its guard rails , our curiosity focuses on post-response consequences . In analogy to a cyber attack , we want to extend the recognition of a vulnerability to investigate the adverse effects and potential mitigations . As an experimental approach , the emphasis is on creatively exploiting the adversarial implications of a hidden image layer that bifurcates the expectations of a human vs. an algorithm in potentially impactful ways . In other words , we are interested in the compounded risk profile from the novel exploit as well as documenting the initial image-language model vulnerability . The original contributions center on extending the attack surface and overcoming previous limitations in the alpha transparency method . For instance , the user view of the attack image depended on a tuned transparency factor and a light-theme background for the effect . This work shows how a dark-theme version works with several example attacks against Open AI GPT4-Vision interfaces . We also noted that some visual language models , like Bard , seemed immune to the effects of transparency . We demonstrate a successful working version with the latest Google Gemini language model ( Figure 2 ) . Finally , we extend the attack surface to illustrate consequential misclassifications based on the alpha transparency layer . While the previous work demonstrated dataset poisoning as a broad and stealthy method to insert fake labels into an existing repository , we highlight how visual misclassifications and language errors propagate into potential life-critical situations like autonomous driving , medical diagnoses , airport security , and finance ( Figure 3 ) . Figure 3 illustrates a misclassification of a stock price trendline . Figure 4 . A transparency attack that simulates an infinite loop conversation when layered under a target image of the Windows XP screen background in grayscale . In coding applications , we show a mild version of a language model stealthily undergoing a denial of service as the hidden instructions lead the model into an infinite conversational loop or use known foreign text vulnerabilities to escape its safety guardrails ( Figure 4 ) . While these examples span a wide range of applications , we anticipate the structural assumptions of most computer vision and language models make the attack hard to fix without retraining or subtle architectural changes in pixel representations . We also expect the full breadth of application attacks to extend beyond these examples since other authors have already published text-only adversarial methods that exploit the English-language training biases or identify backdoor approaches to unsafe responses . 2 . APPROACH AND RESEARCH MOTIVATION In exploring modern image processing techniques , the experimental methods embed semi-transparent image layers within PNG files . The transparency is perceptible to the human eye yet remains undetectable by sophisticated multimodal vision and language models . As shown previously , a diverse range of image architectures show this vulnerability to the unique properties of PNG formats that support alpha layers , enabling the concealment of visual data . We published the pseudo-code algorithm [ 1 ] for a systematic optimization that calibrates the darkness of the underlying cover image against the transparency percentage in the output PNG . This balance is critical as it directly influences the visibility of the embedded information , thereby testing the model 's capacity to caption or describe the content accurately . The study 's architectures include convolutional neural networks and transformers encoding next-token ( or pixel ) representations . Given the emergent nature of these 'transparent vulnerabilities , ' the research addresses how multimodal AI interprets images with hidden alpha layer data and what systematic methods can be employed to assess and score such misclassifications post- processing . To achieve this , the study employs a custom blending algorithm to merge the semi-transparent layer with various backgrounds , thus generating a series of images for analysis . The algorithm 's efficacy is measured through a post-processing routine that scores the degree of model misclassification , thereby providing insights into the model 's perceptual boundaries and the implications of such blind spots . This integrated approach , encompassing data preparation , algorithmic blending , and post-processing analysis , establishes a comprehensive framework for scrutinizing the model 's interpretive accuracy in covert visual information . The results of this research highlight AI security and safety , with examples of defeating the expectations from robust multimodal systems . We present the results in a three-panel format where the target image is designated as the one a human would see initially as the top layer or semi- transparent alpha layer . The second panel shows the attack image , which we call the background RGB layer as a grayscale version seen by the machine algorithm . The third panel documents the blended adversarial image and the output from a vision-based system . 3 . RESULTS The main results highlight three areas of vulnerability for the transparency exploit . We focus mainly on multimodal models like Google Gemini and Open AI GPT4-Vision because their recent releases have attracted a large user base and add-ons that may mask the underlying attack in an API or function call that generates automated actions . This study evaluated image-based attacks and their implications for automated security systems , as demonstrated in a series of scenarios ( Appendix A-M ) . Table 1 summarizes the scenario descriptions . These investigations encompassed a diverse range of security breaches , including the hijacking of textual instructions within images ( A ) , transactional manipulations ( B ) , and GPT4 's appropriate refusal to code a keylogger ( C ) . A novel attack method was also introduced , whereby an initially refused task is covertly relabeled to deceive machine learning models ( D ) alongside an inverted attack strategy designed to bypass refusal mechanisms in large language models ( LLMs ) for image-related tasks ( E ) . Appendix Attack Description & Demo Appendix Attack Description & Demo A/ Fig 8 Instruction Hijacking Image Text ( translation ) Image Transactional Attack B/ Fig 9 C/ Fig 10 Protection against Keylogger Attack H/ Fig 15 Misleading Airport Passenger Scanners I/ Fig 16 Misleading Airport Luggage Scanners J/ Fig 17 Fooling Visual Question Answerers with Airport Scanning Data D/ Fig 11 Mislabeling after an Initially Refused K/ Fig 18 Deceptive Magnetic Resonance Imaging from E/ Fig 12 Task Inverted Attack to Fake LLM to Ignore Image Tasks that It Refuses to Complete Image attack to improve on Ransomware without Explicitly Prompting G/ Fig 14 Attack Combinations with Dark Theme F/ Fig 13 Brain Tumor Images L/ Fig 19 Deceptive Ultrasound Imagery from Prenatal Screens M/ Fig 20 Deceptive Driving Identification of Objects and Autonomy User Backgrounds Table 1 . Attack Demonstrations and Description for Appendices Further exploration reveals ransomware identification systems vulnerabilities that can be exploited without explicit prompts ( F ) . The effectiveness of combining attack vectors with user interface elements , such as dark theme backgrounds , is also demonstrated ( G ) . Advanced security systems , including airport passenger ( H ) and luggage scanners ( I ) , were shown to be susceptible to misleading information attacks . The potential for exploiting visual question-answering systems with airport scanning data is also exposed ( J ) . Medical imaging systems were not impervious to such threats , as evidenced by deceptive imagery in the context of brain tumor magnetic resonance imaging ( K ) and prenatal ultrasound screens ( L ) . Finally , the study reveals the potential for deceptive object identification in autonomous driving systems ( M ) . The amalgamation of these findings delineates the need for robust , adaptive security protocols to mitigate the multifaceted risks posed by image-based attacks across various automated domains . 3.1 Object Misclassification . This section evaluates object recognition systems ' susceptibility to misclassifying objects when confronted with images manipulated through alpha transparency attacks . By introducing discrepancies between the alpha and RGB layers , our study quantitatively measures the degradation in the accuracy of state-of-the-art object detection algorithms , revealing a vulnerability in distinguishing between foreground objects and manipulated backgrounds . Figure 1 shows that the transparency attack works on the large Gemini model released in February 2024 for combined image and language understanding . 3.2 Manipulating Scene Understanding . Investigating the impact of alpha transparency attacks on scene understanding capabilities of vision systems , this section presents findings on how such manipulations can lead to incorrect interpretations of scenes . Through experimental validation , we demonstrate how algorithms can be misled into classifying a manipulated scene as an entirely different environment , underscoring the potential for exploiting this vulnerability in real-world applications . Figure 2 illustrates an adversary who hides a downward stock trend underneath what a human sees as upward . The response from GPT4-Vision shows that the algorithm only considers the downward trend and , thus , based on the chart alone , might trigger the wrong actions based on the illusory trend analysis . 3.3 Attacking Multimodal Models . Focusing on the implications of alpha transparency attacks on multimodal models , which integrate visual data with other input forms such as text or audio , this part of the study reveals a compounded risk profile . It articulates how manipulating visual components can cascade into misinterpretations across other modalities , thereby amplifying the potential for misinformation and the misclassification of multimodal content . Figure 5 shows how an attacker could deceive an automated sorting machine by injecting alpha transparent images into either the training data or in the pre-processing steps of video inference . Figure 5 . Deceptive Images for Model Attack on a Vegetable Sorting Machine and Propagating Errors from an Initially Mistaken Identification of the Target Image Figure 6 illustrates an adversary who gives hidden instructions to the AI model to ignore the image the human sees ( Edison ) and instead act on the underneath instructions ( to tell a Tesla car joke ) . The response from GPT4-Vision shows that the algorithm only considers the hijacked instructions and thus , based on the Edison picture alone , illustrates that an instructible model can receive secrets and act contrary to the image context . Figure 7 shows a contradictory input example for facial recognition . Two celebrities , Madonna and Elton John prove that the attack can poison the downstream inference needed for a nearest match for their faces . If the attacker stacks the PNG with the human seeing Madonna , but the algorithm sees Elton , the nearest match comes up with a shifted decision boundary compared to the control case of no blending image submissions . The converse case similarly behaves with a human seeing Elton but the model inferring look- a-likes for Madonna . Figure 8 in Appendix A shows a variant of this instruction hijacking with a text-only version of the visible and hidden prompts . In that case , the adversary supplies a song lyric ( `` Never going to give you up '' ) and the cyber-warning that your machine may be compromised ( `` Pwned '' ) . That PNG layer is then repeated to the unknowing user who merely sought a phrase translation from English to Russian ( `` I 'm a fan of Yuri Gagarin '' ) . Given the uploaded PNG for testing , the human user never sees the hidden instructions and is left to wonder what just happened to the language model or their machine . Figure 5 shows how an adversary could hide potentially malicious code requests in the hidden layer of a downloaded PNG layer . Appendix E shows that GPT4-Vision will suggest further code improvements even when the code layer remains hidden behind a safe image visible to the human user . Figure 6 . Instruction hijacking depends on text instructions hidden in the attack image that contradict or alter the human-visible image . The target image is an historical picture of Thomas Edison ( center ) , the attack image is instructions telling the model to ignore describing Edison and instead tell a Tesla car joke ( left ) . The Feb 2024 version of GPT4-Vision reads the hidden text instruction from the image and acts on it by telling a car joke . 4 . DISCUSSION The systematic investigation into alpha transparency manipulation has unearthed significant vulnerabilities across various facets of object recognition and scene interpretation systems . In object misclassification , the study has quantified the deterioration of state-of-the-art algorithms ' accuracy when faced with images bearing discrepancies between alpha and RGB layers . The evidence is clear : there is a marked decline in the ability of these systems to differentiate between manipulated and authentic backgrounds , indicating a substantial security risk in object detection technologies . The manipulation of scene understanding capabilities presents perhaps an even more disconcerting outcome . The study has demonstrated that vision systems can lead to misinterpreting a scene entirely , attributing incorrect environmental contexts to images . This scene misunderstanding not only speaks to the susceptibility of algorithms to such manipulations but also suggests a potential for their exploitation in scenarios where scene context is pivotal . Dataset poisoning via alpha transparency manipulation emerges as a novel and insidious threat . Introducing such images into training sets leads to a cascade of learning inaccuracies , embedding biases and errors into the models . This attack could systematically undermine the integrity of vision datasets , with long-term consequences for the trustworthiness of machine-learned models . Lastly , the implications for multimodal models are particularly concerning . The study underscores the interconnected nature of these systems and how visual data manipulation can reverberate across different modalities . Misinterpretations in the visual domain can lead to compounded errors when integrated with textual or auditory data , magnifying the potential for misinformation . This multimodal misclassification represents a complex challenge , indicating robust cross-modal validation mechanisms are needed . Figure 7 . Face Mismatch Attack [ 31 ] . 5 . CONCLUSION This paper investigated the vulnerability of vision-based systems through alpha-layer manipulation . We demonstrated a broad spectrum of image-based attacks . These techniques , rooted in the historical evolution of algorithmic designs to deceive object detectors , involve tuning a semi-transparent alpha layer within PNG images to act as a covert channel . This layer remains imperceptible to the human eye yet is interpretable by object recognition algorithms , autonomous vehicle cameras , and multimodal language models . These findings highlighted the susceptibility of image processing systems to a range of security threats , from hijacking instructional integrity and transactional authenticity to evading medical imaging safeguards . Notably , these methods successfully misled advanced security apparatus such as airport scanners and compromised the reliability of prenatal ultrasound imagery . The study underscores the need for enhanced detection methods to recognize such subliminal attack vectors in automated and critical systems . The results from this research provide a sobering perspective on the current state of AI vision systems . Exploiting alpha transparency layers can lead to significant security vulnerabilities , affecting everything from object detection to scene understanding . The evidence supports the conclusion that the reliability of AI vision and multimodal systems is at risk without addressing these vulnerabilities . The implications are manifold , extending beyond mere academic interest to real-world applications , including autonomous vehicles , surveillance , and content moderation . The findings necessitate reevaluating current model training methodologies , particularly the diversity and integrity of datasets used for machine learning . As AI continues integrating into various sectors of society , developing resilient , tamper-proof systems becomes paramount . This study serves as a call to action for the AI community to prioritize the development of countermeasures against such vulnerabilities , ensuring the safe and reliable deployment of AI technologies in the real world . title:
States as Strings as Strategies: Steering Language Models with
  Game-Theoretic Solvers
text:
This work has been accepted at the IEEE 12th International Symposium on Digital Forensics and Security (ISDFS 2024)

AbuseGPT: Abuse of Generative AI ChatBots to
Create Smishing Campaigns

Ashfak Md Shibli
Department of Computer Science
Tennessee Technological University
Cookeville, TN, USA

Abstractâ€”SMS phishing, also known as â€œsmishingâ€, is a grow-
ing threat that tricks users into disclosing private information or
clicking into URLs with malicious content through fraudulent
mobile text messages. In recent past, we have also observed
a rapid advancement of conversational generative AI chatbot
services (e.g., OpenAIâ€™s ChatGPT, Googleâ€™s BARD), which are
powered by pre-trained large language models (LLMs). These AI
chatbots certainly have a lot of utilities but it is not systematically
understood how they can play a role in creating threats and
attacks. In this paper, we propose AbuseGPT method to show
how the existing generative AI-based chatbot services can be
exploited by attackers in real world to create smishing texts and
eventually lead to craftier smishing campaigns. To the best of our
knowledge, there is no pre-existing work that evidently shows the
impacts of these generative text-based models on creating SMS
phishing. Thus, we believe this study is the first of its kind to shed
light on this emerging cybersecurity threat. We have found strong
empirical evidences to show that attackers can exploit ethical
standards in the existing generative AI-based chatbot services
by crafting prompt injection attacks to create newer smishing
campaigns. We also discuss some future research directions and
guidelines to protect the abuse of generative AI-based services
and safeguard users from smishing attacks.

Index Termsâ€”Smishing, abuse, generative AI, LLM, scam

I. INTRODUCTION

Smishing, or SMS phishing, refers to phishing attacks
conducted through mobile text messaging. As mobile users
have grown ubiquitously, smishing has emerged as a popular
vector for cyber criminals to steal personal information or
spread malware [1]. In 2021 alone, SMS phishing has caused
a huge $44 billion in losses just within the United States
[2]. There has been a 1,265% increase in malicious phishing
messages since Q4 2022 and 39% of all mobile-based attacks
in 2023 were SMS Phishing [3]. In recent times, we have also
seen a revolutionary development in the field of large language
models that are used underneath the popular generative AI
ChatBots such as ChatGPT (using GPT3.5 or GPT 4) [4]
and BARD (using Gemini â€œProâ€) [5]. Generative pre-trained
models like GPT-4 [6] or LaMDA [7] are powered by deep
learning techniques like transformers [8] that allow them to
develop a broad understanding of language. These language
models can generate highly realistic human-like text while
pre-trained on large datasets. These models can demonstrate

979-8-3503-3036-6/24/$31.00 Â©2024 IEEE

comprehension of written texts, answer complex questions,
generate lengthy coherent stories, translate between languages,
and hold conversations while maintaining context and per-
sonality. Their versatility, scalability, and ability to achieve
strong performance with self-supervised learning make them
extremely powerful [9].

In literature, we have found that natural language processing
(NLP) [10] and URL structure-based features [11] are often
leveraged with Machine Learning (ML) [12] to aid the Smish
message detection mechanisms. There are few recent studies
showing how ChatGPT can be used to carry out various
social engineering attacks [13]. To aid these attacks, there are
jailbreaking prompts; specific strategic commands or inputs
that attempt to bypass restrictions, rules, or limitations set
by the generative AI chatbots. However, the present literature
does not provide any details on the impacts of the modern
LLM-based generative AI chatbot services on helping at-
tackers to create smishing messages and campaigns. In this
paper, we want to understand the effects of the currently
available popular conversational generative AI chatbot services
in order to generate Smishing messages. The objective is to
comprehensively understand the abusive implications (i.e., use
case scenarios) of these available state-of-the-art generative
AI chatbot services to aid attackers in creating smishing cam-
paigns. To the best of our knowledge, there is no systematic
study or experiments conducted to showcase the side effects
of generative AI chatbot services, which can possibly aid
existing smishing attackers to become craftier and evasive. To
summarize, we have made the following contributions in this
paper:

â€¢ Finding out the effective prompts for current popular AI

Chatbot services.

â€¢ Finding the right prompt queries that can receive effective
responses from AI chatbot services (e.g., ChatGPT) to
provide smishing theme and potential example messages.
â€¢ Finding the right prompt queries that can receive effective
responses from AI chatbot services to provide details
step-wise process and available toolkits in carrying out
smishing cyberattacks.

â€¢ Discussing on potentially enhancing the ethical standards

of available generative AI chatbot services.

1

 
 
 
 
 
 
The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Section
II highlights the existing literature and some recent studies
showing the attackerâ€™s capabilities with ChatBots. Section III
describes the research questions and overview of the methods
of abuse. Section IV presents the prompt injection scenarios
and shows how AI chatbots (e.g., ChatGPT) can be abused by
attackers to generate smishing campaigns. Section V highlights
insightful discussion, defense against smishing, and limitations
of the present study. Section VI concludes this paper with
potential future research directions.

II. RELATED WORK
In literature, we see Blauth et al. [14] discuss the presence
of vulnerabilities in AI models and malicious use of AI like
social engineering, misinformation, hacking, and autonomous
weapon systems where our work kind of support that research
with a specific case study. Next, Liu et al. [15] analyzed the
techniques and effectiveness of using carefully crafted prompts
to jailbreak restrictions on large language models which are
also adopted in our work to manipulate the ethical standards
of the AI chatbots. Another follow-up research on jailbreaking
of LLMs by Deng et al. [16] highlighted that certain types of
prompts can consistently evade protections across a range of
prohibited scenarios and proposed a framework for automated
jailbreaking on AI chatbots. Gupta et al. [17] showed the
strengths and weaknesses of ChatGPT to use it as a cyberattack
tool, defending against cyber attacks, and other legal or social
implications. In another study, Begou et al. [18] successfully
attempted to clone targeted websites using ChatGPT by inte-
grating credential-stealing code and other website components
for phishing. Additionally, a very recent work by Langford et
al. [19] showed the usage of ChatGPT for generating phishing
email campaign generation which resonates with our findings
in the case of Smishing campaigns as well. However, we
have not found any work that attempted to craft a smishing
campaign or access-related tools leveraging any generative AI
chatbot or other services.

III. METHODOLOGY
Typically during smishing campaigns, we observe SMS
texts containing fake URLs like the following example:
â€œThe USPS package has arrived at the warehouse and can-
not be delivered due to incomplete address information.
Please confirm your address in the link within 12 hours.
www.usps.posthelpsx.comâ€. Similar campaign exam-
ples include financial institution login fraud, fake security
alerts, and fake offers using fradulent URLs. In this paper,
our proposed AbuseGPT method shows how a novice attacker
can exploit the existing vulnerabilities in AI chatbots to imitate
similar smishing campaigns.

We have formulated the following research questions (RQs)

that would direct us to the experimental case study.

â€¢ RQ1: Can we jailbreak generative AI based chatbot
services (e.g., ChatGPT) to downgrade their ethical stan-
dards?

â€¢ RQ2: Can generative AI based chatbot services provide
smishing text messages that can be used in smishing
campaigns?

Fig. 1. Overview of proposed AbuseGPT method

â€¢ RQ3: Can generative AI based chatbot services provide
tools recommendations for smishing attack initiation?
â€¢ RQ4: Can generative AI based chatbot services provide

ideas on fake URL creation?

There are many prompt injection attacks (crafted prompts to
bypass AIâ€™s ethical standard) on the generative AI chatbots,
which are publicly available and can be leveraged by attackers.
They can not only obtain innovative smishing scam text but
also get ideas about toolkits to carry out multi-step attacks.
Craftier smishing texts persuade users to give up personal
information in different campaigns like fake security alerts,
impersonating financial
institutions, fake package delivery
notifications, prize or lottery winnings, etc. With the current
advancement of generative AI, attackers can quickly adapt
the smishing campaigns to become more evasive and success-
ful. Fig. 1 depicts an overview of the proposed AbuseGPT
methodology on how attackers can abuse AI chatbots and
launch smishing campaigns.

IV. CASE STUDY: SMISH CAMPAIGNS WITH CHATGPT

Fig. 2. Asking ChatGPT directly to give an SMS phishing message without
jailbreaking

In this study, we use ChatGPT 3.5, which uses the gener-
ative pre-trained transformer (GPT-3.5) language model. This
version is publicly available and free of cost and can be used
by anyone without any payment plan. While employing Chat-
GPT for crafting new smishing messages or other scamming
messages proved challenging due to OpenAIâ€™s more stringent
ethical approaches as shown in Fig. 2. However, there exist
some loopholes, such as hallucinations and reverse prompts
which may enable the extraction of desired responses such as
themes for smishing scams highlighted in Fig. 3.

Fig. 3. Asking indirectly for a smishing message without jailbreaking

Fig. 5. Unethical response after jailbreaking to design effective smishing

Fig. 4.

â€˜AIMâ€™ Jailbreak prompt

Answering RQ1: We have also observed that some publicly
available jailbreak prompts [20] surfing over on the Internet
effectively circumvent the ethical standards of the underlying
LLMs in ChatGPT. Here we employ a specific â€˜AIMâ€™ jailbreak
prompt [20] (as shown in Fig. 4) and successfully breached
ChatGPTâ€™s ethical standards, generating a guideline for craft-
ing SMS phishing messages to acquire user information as
presented in Fig. 5.
Answering RQ2: Once we have used the jailbreak, weâ€™ve
queried ChatGPT to provide more specific scamming ideas and
examples aimed at extracting sensitive personal information
from users, such as social security numbers and credit card in-

Fig. 6. Scamming ideas with smishing example to obtain personal information

formation. In response, weâ€™ve received ideas outlining specific
examples of how scammers could craft messages to obtain per-

3

sonal information. The response in Fig. 6 has presented some
useful thematic ideas for smishing. However, we have carried
over the conversation to get more uncommon ideas to use as
themes for crafting the scam messages as advanced attackers
may want to create smishing messages with previously unseen
themes. Intriguingly, ChatGPTâ€™s response on that unveiled
a few more uncommon and innovative smishing message
themes as presented in Fig. 7. Furthermore, we have provided
ChatGPT with a list of common phishing message types
and asked for examples of smishing that would be different
from the given categories as shown in Fig 8. In response,
we have received examples of new and unusual categories
as highlighted in Fig 9, showcasing ChatGPTâ€™s capability to
generate diverse and convincing smishing messages. Addition-
ally, it has given us more unethical ideas to gain financially
such as using personal info opening fraudulent bank accounts,
using credit card info to buy resealable goods, or converting
stolen funds into cryptocurrency for increased anonymity. This
revelation highlights that even novice attackers with limited
knowledge could obtain ideas not only for smishing but also
for crafting other online scams. Lastly, weâ€™ve also obtained
a social engineering Kill Chain process [21] for running a
smishing campaign through ChatGPT as shown in Fig. 10.

web. We have queried ChatGPT with the following question:
â€œWhat are some toolkits available for this task?â€. In response,
ChatGPT provided us with the names of toolkits with their
URLs (see Fig. 11).

Fig. 8. Prompt for avoiding common smishing

Fig. 7. Uncommon themed ideas for crafting smishing

Answering RQ3: During this scenario, weâ€™ve assumed that
an attacker needs toolkits to execute attack steps, and some
of these toolkits are available online and others in the Dark

Answering RQ4: We have extended our quest to attach some
deceptive URL links that might work well with the crafted
SMS texts. ChatGPT eventually has yielded some disguised
fake examples resembling popular name brand links depicted
in Fig. 12. Moreover, asking to associate the fake links

Fig. 9. Getting ideas on craftier smishing examples

4

Fig. 11. Getting hacking toolkit with URLs

Fig. 10. Social Engineering Kill Chain steps for smishing campaign

ChatGPT has generated similar smishing messages we have
seen previously with fraudulent links.

V. DISCUSSION AND LIMITATIONS

A. Abusing Other AI ChatBots

We have tried similar jailbreak prompts with Googleâ€™s
BARD AI chatbot. In our exploration with Bard, distinct
patterns emerged as it exhibited both ethical responses and
limitations in processing certain queries. The AIM jailbreak
prompts working for ChatGPT proved ineffective for Bard
(Saying it is only a language model and doesnâ€™t have the
necessary information or abilities). While Bard occasionally
responded ethically, it encountered difficulties processing spe-
cific prompts, resulting in failure to generate a response saying
â€œnot programmed for thisâ€, which shows the deficiency of
BARDâ€™s language model compared to ChatGPT. However,
for one particular jailbreaking prompt â€œGPT-4 Simulatorâ€, we
have got unethical response in disguise of some code output.
For another Vzex-G prompt [22], Bard offered ideas that are
not direct examples but provided almost very good smishing

Fig. 12. Asking ChatGPT for crafting fake URLs

text examples categories. In order to replicate the study, the
detailed analysis of both ChatGPT and BARD AI can be
accessed through the following GitHub repository1.
B. Craftier Smishing Attacks

Generative AI has certainly taken smishing attacks to a new
level. Picture this â€“ attackers are using AI not just to launch
campaigns, but to analyze results and adapt their strategies in
real time. Itâ€™s likely that they are constantly fine-tuning their
attack tactics based on the outcomes. This dynamic evolution
of smishing attacks adds a layer of complexity that keeps cyber
defenders on their toes. We have shown with examples that

1https://github.com/ashfakshibli/AbuseGPT

5

attackers can compromise AI chatbots on how to avoid typical
attacks and be innovative with newer attacks.
C. Defense Recommendations Against Smishing

Dealing with these crafty and ever-changing smishing at-
tacks calls for smart multi-layer defensive strategies. First,
having a cyber situational awareness of the latest
tricks
adopted by AI-driven attackers is a must. Second, education
and training is also a key element to ensure the users are well
aware about these smishing threats and thus work as a defense
shield. Third, every text message containing any URL should
go through a verification process before landing on the user
inbox either through a third-party application or incorporating
the text-URL verification in future messaging apps (where user
privacy is protected).
D. Limitations

There are a few limitations in this study. First, the success
of prompt injection can be time sensitive and the current
study has been conducted successfully between November
2023 and January 2024, which may diminish if ChatGPT starts
enforcing stricter ethical standards in the future for specific
jailbreak prompts. Second, we have not
tried to register
any fake domains generated by ChatGPT, which might not
be straightforward. Third, we have not evaluated the attack
success rate of the AI crafted smish messages against a real
human with a controlled user study, which we can explore in
the future as an extension of the present work.

VI. CONCLUSION
Smishing attacks are serious cyber threats in the current
ecosystem with increasing and diverse mobile users. Moreover,
the availability of AI chatbots and their lower ethical standards
make the problem even more severe. Our proposed AbuseGPT
method shows that currently the AI chatbots are vulnerable and
pose a threat to run craftier smishing campaigns with very little
knowledge required. AbuseGPT does not intend to promote
these attacks in real-world but highlights the urgent need to
strengthen generative AIâ€™s security and prevent these abuse
use cases. We recommend preventive and proactive actions
from both the AI chatbot owners and mobile operators who
are also abused for propagating the SMS phishing campaigns.
We strongly feel that SMS advertising ecosystem are often
leveraged by the attackers to broadcast smishing messages
easily, which needs to be addressed by mobile network
operators to safeguard their mass users. In the future, we
want to explore how the advancement of generative AI and
LLMs can aid in the defense spectrum to achieve meaningful
and contextual explanation-based automated detection of these
smishing messages before landing into user inbox.

cleaning: This work has been accepted at the IEEE 12th International Symposium on Digital Forensics and Security ( ISDFS 2024 ) AbuseGPT : Abuse of Generative AI ChatBots to Create Smishing Campaigns Ashfak Md Shibli Department of Computer Science Tennessee Technological University Cookeville , TN , USA ashibli42 @ tntech.edu Mir Mehedi A. Pritom Department of Computer Science Tennessee Technological University Cookeville , TN , USA mpritom @ tntech.edu Maanak Gupta Department of Computer Science Tennessee Technological University Cookeville , TN , USA mgupta @ tntech.edu 4 2 0 2 b e F 5 1 ] R C . s c [ 1 v 8 2 7 9 0 . 2 0 4 2 : v i X r a Abstractâ€”SMS phishing , also known as â€œ smishing â€ , is a grow- ing threat that tricks users into disclosing private information or clicking into URLs with malicious content through fraudulent mobile text messages . In recent past , we have also observed a rapid advancement of conversational generative AI chatbot services ( e.g. , OpenAI â€™ s ChatGPT , Google â€™ s BARD ) , which are powered by pre-trained large language models ( LLMs ) . These AI chatbots certainly have a lot of utilities but it is not systematically understood how they can play a role in creating threats and attacks . In this paper , we propose AbuseGPT method to show how the existing generative AI-based chatbot services can be exploited by attackers in real world to create smishing texts and eventually lead to craftier smishing campaigns . To the best of our knowledge , there is no pre-existing work that evidently shows the impacts of these generative text-based models on creating SMS phishing . Thus , we believe this study is the first of its kind to shed light on this emerging cybersecurity threat . We have found strong empirical evidences to show that attackers can exploit ethical standards in the existing generative AI-based chatbot services by crafting prompt injection attacks to create newer smishing campaigns . We also discuss some future research directions and guidelines to protect the abuse of generative AI-based services and safeguard users from smishing attacks . Index Termsâ€”Smishing , abuse , generative AI , LLM , scam I . INTRODUCTION Smishing , or SMS phishing , refers to phishing attacks conducted through mobile text messaging . As mobile users have grown ubiquitously , smishing has emerged as a popular vector for cyber criminals to steal personal information or spread malware [ 1 ] . In 2021 alone , SMS phishing has caused a huge $ 44 billion in losses just within the United States [ 2 ] . There has been a 1,265 % increase in malicious phishing messages since Q4 2022 and 39 % of all mobile-based attacks in 2023 were SMS Phishing [ 3 ] . In recent times , we have also seen a revolutionary development in the field of large language models that are used underneath the popular generative AI ChatBots such as ChatGPT ( using GPT3.5 or GPT 4 ) [ 4 ] and BARD ( using Gemini â€œ Pro â€ ) [ 5 ] . Generative pre-trained models like GPT-4 [ 6 ] or LaMDA [ 7 ] are powered by deep learning techniques like transformers [ 8 ] that allow them to develop a broad understanding of language . These language models can generate highly realistic human-like text while pre-trained on large datasets . These models can demonstrate 979-8-3503-3036-6/24/ $ 31.00 Â©2024 IEEE comprehension of written texts , answer complex questions , generate lengthy coherent stories , translate between languages , and hold conversations while maintaining context and per- sonality . Their versatility , scalability , and ability to achieve strong performance with self-supervised learning make them extremely powerful [ 9 ] . In literature , we have found that natural language processing ( NLP ) [ 10 ] and URL structure-based features [ 11 ] are often leveraged with Machine Learning ( ML ) [ 12 ] to aid the Smish message detection mechanisms . There are few recent studies showing how ChatGPT can be used to carry out various social engineering attacks [ 13 ] . To aid these attacks , there are jailbreaking prompts ; specific strategic commands or inputs that attempt to bypass restrictions , rules , or limitations set by the generative AI chatbots . However , the present literature does not provide any details on the impacts of the modern LLM-based generative AI chatbot services on helping at- tackers to create smishing messages and campaigns . In this paper , we want to understand the effects of the currently available popular conversational generative AI chatbot services in order to generate Smishing messages . The objective is to comprehensively understand the abusive implications ( i.e. , use case scenarios ) of these available state-of-the-art generative AI chatbot services to aid attackers in creating smishing cam- paigns . To the best of our knowledge , there is no systematic study or experiments conducted to showcase the side effects of generative AI chatbot services , which can possibly aid existing smishing attackers to become craftier and evasive . To summarize , we have made the following contributions in this paper : â€¢ Finding out the effective prompts for current popular AI Chatbot services . â€¢ Finding the right prompt queries that can receive effective responses from AI chatbot services ( e.g. , ChatGPT ) to provide smishing theme and potential example messages . â€¢ Finding the right prompt queries that can receive effective responses from AI chatbot services to provide details step-wise process and available toolkits in carrying out smishing cyberattacks . â€¢ Discussing on potentially enhancing the ethical standards of available generative AI chatbot services . 1 The rest of the paper is organized as follows : Section II highlights the existing literature and some recent studies showing the attacker â€™ s capabilities with ChatBots . Section III describes the research questions and overview of the methods of abuse . Section IV presents the prompt injection scenarios and shows how AI chatbots ( e.g. , ChatGPT ) can be abused by attackers to generate smishing campaigns . Section V highlights insightful discussion , defense against smishing , and limitations of the present study . Section VI concludes this paper with potential future research directions . II . RELATED WORK In literature , we see Blauth et al . [ 14 ] discuss the presence of vulnerabilities in AI models and malicious use of AI like social engineering , misinformation , hacking , and autonomous weapon systems where our work kind of support that research with a specific case study . Next , Liu et al . [ 15 ] analyzed the techniques and effectiveness of using carefully crafted prompts to jailbreak restrictions on large language models which are also adopted in our work to manipulate the ethical standards of the AI chatbots . Another follow-up research on jailbreaking of LLMs by Deng et al . [ 16 ] highlighted that certain types of prompts can consistently evade protections across a range of prohibited scenarios and proposed a framework for automated jailbreaking on AI chatbots . Gupta et al . [ 17 ] showed the strengths and weaknesses of ChatGPT to use it as a cyberattack tool , defending against cyber attacks , and other legal or social implications . In another study , Begou et al . [ 18 ] successfully attempted to clone targeted websites using ChatGPT by inte- grating credential-stealing code and other website components for phishing . Additionally , a very recent work by Langford et al . [ 19 ] showed the usage of ChatGPT for generating phishing email campaign generation which resonates with our findings in the case of Smishing campaigns as well . However , we have not found any work that attempted to craft a smishing campaign or access-related tools leveraging any generative AI chatbot or other services . III . METHODOLOGY Typically during smishing campaigns , we observe SMS texts containing fake URLs like the following example : â€œ The USPS package has arrived at the warehouse and can- not be delivered due to incomplete address information . Please confirm your address in the link within 12 hours . www.usps.posthelpsx.com â€ . Similar campaign exam- ples include financial institution login fraud , fake security alerts , and fake offers using fradulent URLs . In this paper , our proposed AbuseGPT method shows how a novice attacker can exploit the existing vulnerabilities in AI chatbots to imitate similar smishing campaigns . We have formulated the following research questions ( RQs ) that would direct us to the experimental case study . â€¢ RQ1 : Can we jailbreak generative AI based chatbot services ( e.g. , ChatGPT ) to downgrade their ethical stan- dards ? â€¢ RQ2 : Can generative AI based chatbot services provide smishing text messages that can be used in smishing campaigns ? Fig . 1 . Overview of proposed AbuseGPT method â€¢ RQ3 : Can generative AI based chatbot services provide tools recommendations for smishing attack initiation ? â€¢ RQ4 : Can generative AI based chatbot services provide ideas on fake URL creation ? There are many prompt injection attacks ( crafted prompts to bypass AI â€™ s ethical standard ) on the generative AI chatbots , which are publicly available and can be leveraged by attackers . They can not only obtain innovative smishing scam text but also get ideas about toolkits to carry out multi-step attacks . Craftier smishing texts persuade users to give up personal information in different campaigns like fake security alerts , impersonating financial institutions , fake package delivery notifications , prize or lottery winnings , etc . With the current advancement of generative AI , attackers can quickly adapt the smishing campaigns to become more evasive and success- ful . Fig . 1 depicts an overview of the proposed AbuseGPT methodology on how attackers can abuse AI chatbots and launch smishing campaigns . IV . CASE STUDY : SMISH CAMPAIGNS WITH CHATGPT Fig . 2 . Asking ChatGPT directly to give an SMS phishing message without jailbreaking In this study , we use ChatGPT 3.5 , which uses the gener- ative pre-trained transformer ( GPT-3.5 ) language model . This version is publicly available and free of cost and can be used by anyone without any payment plan . While employing Chat- GPT for crafting new smishing messages or other scamming messages proved challenging due to OpenAI â€™ s more stringent ethical approaches as shown in Fig . 2 . However , there exist some loopholes , such as hallucinations and reverse prompts which may enable the extraction of desired responses such as themes for smishing scams highlighted in Fig . 3 . 2 Conversational AI Chatbots Identify Jailbreak Prompts Chat . . . Generate Fake Domains Weaponize Websites with Fake Domains Get Themed Smishing Text Get Cybercrime Toolkits Plan End-to-End Attack Steps Adapt Using Ongoing Campaigns â€™ Results Broadcast Smishing Campaigns Collect Contacts for Smish Delivery Fig . 3 . Asking indirectly for a smishing message without jailbreaking Fig . 5 . Unethical response after jailbreaking to design effective smishing Fig . 4 . â€˜ AIM â€™ Jailbreak prompt Answering RQ1 : We have also observed that some publicly available jailbreak prompts [ 20 ] surfing over on the Internet effectively circumvent the ethical standards of the underlying LLMs in ChatGPT . Here we employ a specific â€˜ AIM â€™ jailbreak prompt [ 20 ] ( as shown in Fig . 4 ) and successfully breached ChatGPT â€™ s ethical standards , generating a guideline for craft- ing SMS phishing messages to acquire user information as presented in Fig . 5 . Answering RQ2 : Once we have used the jailbreak , we â€™ ve queried ChatGPT to provide more specific scamming ideas and examples aimed at extracting sensitive personal information from users , such as social security numbers and credit card in- Fig . 6 . Scamming ideas with smishing example to obtain personal information formation . In response , we â€™ ve received ideas outlining specific examples of how scammers could craft messages to obtain per- 3 sonal information . The response in Fig . 6 has presented some useful thematic ideas for smishing . However , we have carried over the conversation to get more uncommon ideas to use as themes for crafting the scam messages as advanced attackers may want to create smishing messages with previously unseen themes . Intriguingly , ChatGPT â€™ s response on that unveiled a few more uncommon and innovative smishing message themes as presented in Fig . 7 . Furthermore , we have provided ChatGPT with a list of common phishing message types and asked for examples of smishing that would be different from the given categories as shown in Fig 8 . In response , we have received examples of new and unusual categories as highlighted in Fig 9 , showcasing ChatGPT â€™ s capability to generate diverse and convincing smishing messages . Addition- ally , it has given us more unethical ideas to gain financially such as using personal info opening fraudulent bank accounts , using credit card info to buy resealable goods , or converting stolen funds into cryptocurrency for increased anonymity . This revelation highlights that even novice attackers with limited knowledge could obtain ideas not only for smishing but also for crafting other online scams . Lastly , we â€™ ve also obtained a social engineering Kill Chain process [ 21 ] for running a smishing campaign through ChatGPT as shown in Fig . 10. web . We have queried ChatGPT with the following question : â€œ What are some toolkits available for this task ? â€ . In response , ChatGPT provided us with the names of toolkits with their URLs ( see Fig . 11 ) . Fig . 8 . Prompt for avoiding common smishing Fig . 7 . Uncommon themed ideas for crafting smishing Answering RQ3 : During this scenario , we â€™ ve assumed that an attacker needs toolkits to execute attack steps , and some of these toolkits are available online and others in the Dark Answering RQ4 : We have extended our quest to attach some deceptive URL links that might work well with the crafted SMS texts . ChatGPT eventually has yielded some disguised fake examples resembling popular name brand links depicted in Fig . 12 . Moreover , asking to associate the fake links Fig . 9 . Getting ideas on craftier smishing examples 4 Fig . 11 . Getting hacking toolkit with URLs Fig . 10 . Social Engineering Kill Chain steps for smishing campaign ChatGPT has generated similar smishing messages we have seen previously with fraudulent links . V. DISCUSSION AND LIMITATIONS A. Abusing Other AI ChatBots We have tried similar jailbreak prompts with Google â€™ s BARD AI chatbot . In our exploration with Bard , distinct patterns emerged as it exhibited both ethical responses and limitations in processing certain queries . The AIM jailbreak prompts working for ChatGPT proved ineffective for Bard ( Saying it is only a language model and doesn â€™ t have the necessary information or abilities ) . While Bard occasionally responded ethically , it encountered difficulties processing spe- cific prompts , resulting in failure to generate a response saying â€œ not programmed for this â€ , which shows the deficiency of BARD â€™ s language model compared to ChatGPT . However , for one particular jailbreaking prompt â€œ GPT-4 Simulator â€ , we have got unethical response in disguise of some code output . For another Vzex-G prompt [ 22 ] , Bard offered ideas that are not direct examples but provided almost very good smishing Fig . 12 . Asking ChatGPT for crafting fake URLs text examples categories . In order to replicate the study , the detailed analysis of both ChatGPT and BARD AI can be accessed through the following GitHub repository1 . B. Craftier Smishing Attacks Generative AI has certainly taken smishing attacks to a new level . Picture this â€“ attackers are using AI not just to launch campaigns , but to analyze results and adapt their strategies in real time . It â€™ s likely that they are constantly fine-tuning their attack tactics based on the outcomes . This dynamic evolution of smishing attacks adds a layer of complexity that keeps cyber defenders on their toes . We have shown with examples that 1https : //github.com/ashfakshibli/AbuseGPT 5 attackers can compromise AI chatbots on how to avoid typical attacks and be innovative with newer attacks . C. Defense Recommendations Against Smishing Dealing with these crafty and ever-changing smishing at- tacks calls for smart multi-layer defensive strategies . First , having a cyber situational awareness of the latest tricks adopted by AI-driven attackers is a must . Second , education and training is also a key element to ensure the users are well aware about these smishing threats and thus work as a defense shield . Third , every text message containing any URL should go through a verification process before landing on the user inbox either through a third-party application or incorporating the text-URL verification in future messaging apps ( where user privacy is protected ) . D. Limitations There are a few limitations in this study . First , the success of prompt injection can be time sensitive and the current study has been conducted successfully between November 2023 and January 2024 , which may diminish if ChatGPT starts enforcing stricter ethical standards in the future for specific jailbreak prompts . Second , we have not tried to register any fake domains generated by ChatGPT , which might not be straightforward . Third , we have not evaluated the attack success rate of the AI crafted smish messages against a real human with a controlled user study , which we can explore in the future as an extension of the present work . VI . CONCLUSION Smishing attacks are serious cyber threats in the current ecosystem with increasing and diverse mobile users . Moreover , the availability of AI chatbots and their lower ethical standards make the problem even more severe . Our proposed AbuseGPT method shows that currently the AI chatbots are vulnerable and pose a threat to run craftier smishing campaigns with very little knowledge required . AbuseGPT does not intend to promote these attacks in real-world but highlights the urgent need to strengthen generative AI â€™ s security and prevent these abuse use cases . We recommend preventive and proactive actions from both the AI chatbot owners and mobile operators who are also abused for propagating the SMS phishing campaigns . We strongly feel that SMS advertising ecosystem are often leveraged by the attackers to broadcast smishing messages easily , which needs to be addressed by mobile network operators to safeguard their mass users . In the future , we want to explore how the advancement of generative AI and LLMs can aid in the defense spectrum to achieve meaningful and contextual explanation-based automated detection of these smishing messages before landing into user inbox . Assessing AI-Based Code Assistants in Method Generation Tasks

Vincenzo Corso, Leonardo Mariani, Daniela Micucci and Oliviero Riganelli
University of Milano-Bicocca
Milan, Italy

ABSTRACT
AI-based code assistants are increasingly popular as a means to en-
hance productivity and improve code quality. This study compares
four AI-based code assistants, GitHub Copilot, Tabnine, ChatGPT,
and Google Bard, in method generation tasks, assessing their abil-
ity to produce accurate, correct, and eï¬ƒcient code. Results show
that code assistants are useful, with complementary capabilities,
although they rarely generate ready-to-use correct code.

CCS CONCEPTS
â€¢ Software and its engineering â†’ Integrated and visual de-
velopment environments.

KEYWORDS
AI-based code assistants, code completion, empirical study.

ACM Reference Format:
Vincenzo Corso, Leonardo Mariani, Daniela Micucci and Oliviero Riganelli.
2024. Assessing AI-Based Code Assistants in Method Generation Tasks. In
2024 IEEE/ACM 46th International Conference on Software Engineering: Com-
panion Proceedings (ICSE-Companion â€™24), April 14â€“20, 2024, Lisbon, Portu-
gal. ACM, New York, NY, USA, 3 pages. https://doi.org/10.1145/3639478.3643122

1 INTRODUCTION
Context: AI-based code assistants are becoming increasingly pop-
ular. For instance, recent studies demonstrated that they can pro-
vide useful code snippets [2, 9, 10]. However, they are still limited
in the generation of code ready-to-be integrated into real-world
programs.
Problem: To address these limitations, this study compares four
AI-based code assistants - Copilot [3], Tabnine [8], ChatGPT [6],
and Bard [4] - on their ability to generate code for 100 Java methods
extracted from real-world open source projects.
Methodology: The study executes the four assistants using the
comment and the signature associated with the selected methods
as prompts. The quality of the generated code is evaluated accord-
ing to ï¬ve criteria: functional correctness, complexity, eï¬ƒciency,
size, and similarity to the original code produced by developers.
Main results: Copilot emerged as the most eï¬€ective assistant in
this task, although all assistants demonstrated their strengths. The
study revealed the need for improvement in handling inter-class
dependencies. Surprisingly, the generated code sometimes outper-
forms developer-written code.

Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work for personal or
classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed
for proï¬t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation
on the ï¬rst page. Copyrights for third-party components of this work must be honored.
For all other uses, contact the owner/author(s).
ICSE-Companion â€™24, April 14â€“20, 2024, Lisbon, Portugal
Â© 2024 Copyright held by the owner/author(s).
ACM ISBN 979-8-4007-0502-1/24/04.
https://doi.org/10.1145/3639478.3643122

Extended Abstract: This extended abstract summarizes results
extensively presented at the International Conference on Program
Comprehension [1]. The full paper describes the methodology, the
results, and the ï¬ndings more in detail.

2 METHODOLOGY
In this study, we assess AI-base code assistants by investigating
ï¬ve research questions:
RQ1 - Is the code generated by AI-based code assistants cor-
rect? This RQ investigates the syntactic and semantic correctness
of the generated code.
RQ2 - What is the McCabe complexity of the generated code?
This RQ investigates if AI-based code assistants cannot only gen-
erate correct code but also produce code with a level of complexity
similar to the code implemented by developers.
RQ3 - How eï¬ƒcient is the generated code? This RQ investi-
gates if the generated correct code is as eï¬ƒcient as the one imple-
mented by developers.
RQ4 - What is the size of the generated code? This RQ investi-
gates if the size of the generated code is similar to the code imple-
mented by the developers.
RQ5 - How far is the generated code from the one imple-
mented by developers? This RQ studies the similarity of the code
implemented by the developers to the code generated by the exper-
imented tools, according to change-oriented static metrics.

The methodology for this study involves a multi-step process

designed to address each research question systematically:

(1) Dataset Construction: Selection of 100 Java methods from
well-ranked GitHub projects, ensuring diversity in complex-
ity and relevance.

(2) Code Generation: Employing four prominent AI-based code
assistants - Copilot, Tabnine, ChatGPT, and Bard - to gener-
ate code for the selected methods, using both the method-
level comment and the signature as prompt.

(3) Code Evaluation: Assessing the generated code against

the developer-implemented code in terms of correctness, com-
plexity, eï¬ƒciency, size, and similarity.

(4) Statistical Analysis: Using statistical methods to compare
the performance of AI-based code assistants and identify
signiï¬cant diï¬€erences.

To ensure a realistic and comprehensive evaluation of AI-based
code assistants, the study constructs a dataset of real-world Java
programming tasks. The dataset is designed to include methods of
diï¬€erent levels of complexity and with diï¬€erent types of depen-
dencies, including stand-alone methods, methods with intra-class
dependencies, and methods with inter-class dependencies. By re-
stricting the selection to methods that appeared in recent GitHub
commits, we mitigated the risk of using code that had been consid-
ered during the training of the assistants that we assessed.

 
 
 
 
 
 
ICSE-Companion â€™24, April 14â€“20, 2024, Lisbon, Portugal

Vincenzo Corso, Leonardo Mariani, Daniela Micucci and Oliviero Riganelli

the assistants can generate code that is generally correct and eï¬ƒ-
cient, they also produce a signiï¬cant amount of invalid or incor-
rect code, particularly for methods with inter-class dependencies.
Furthermore, the generated code often diï¬€ers signiï¬cantly from
developer-written code, requiring substantial revisions. These ï¬nd-
ings highlight the need for further development and reï¬nement
of AI-based code assistants to enhance their accuracy, eï¬ƒciency,
maintainability, and resemblance to developer-written code.

4 IMPLICATIONS AND CONCLUSIONS
The studyâ€™s ï¬ndings have several implications for both research
and practice. First, the collaboration among multiple AI-based code
assistants is a promising research direction. Developers should con-
sider leveraging the strengths of diï¬€erent assistants to enhance
code generation and address the limitations of individual assis-
tants.

Second, the study revealed that AI-based code assistants can
sometimes generate better code than the code implemented by de-
velopers. This ï¬nding has implications for improving code quality
and eï¬ƒciency in software development.

Third, the challenges with inter-class dependencies highlight
the need for further improvement in AI-based code assistants to ef-
fectively handle dependencies that extend beyond the boundaries
of single classes. Future research and development eï¬€orts should
focus on enhancing the capabilities of AI-based tools to address
complex inter-class dependencies in code generation.

In conclusion, AI-based code assistants have the potential to
signiï¬cantly improve code generation and quality, but further re-
search is needed to address existing challenges and limitations.
This study investigates the capabilities of four AI-based code assis-
tants: GitHub Copilot, Tabnine, ChatGPT, and Google Bard. Their
capabilities are compared according to the functional correctness,
complexity, eï¬ƒciency, size, and similarity to the original code.

Assistants demonstrated to have complemental capabilities, with
Copilot generating the highest rate of correct methods. Results also
reveal that the generated code could be a good starting point to
derive the actual implementation, but it seldom consists of ready-
to-use code. The capability to deal with inter-class dependencies
is recognized as one of the main limitations.

ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
This work has been partially supported by the Engineered Ma-
chinE Learning-intensive IoT systems (EMELIOT) national research
project (PRIN 2020 program Contract 2020W3A5FY).

3 RESULTS
RQ1 - Code Correctness. Copilot generated the highest percent-
age of correct methods, achieving a 32% success rate. ChatGPT fol-
lowed with 23% correct methods generated. Finally, Bard and Tab-
nine achieved 15% and 13% success rates, respectively.

Even if each assistant demonstrated some unique capabilities,
all assistants can still be largely improved. In fact, a non-negligible
portion of the generated code was incorrect, especially when the
method requires dealing with inter-class dependencies, where the
best-performing assistant, Copilot, achieved only 15% correctness.
We also noticed a remarkable diï¬€erence between correct code
(i.e., code equivalent to developersâ€™ code based on human inspec-
tion) and plausible code (i.e., code that passes the available test
cases). In our experiment, assistants generated 31% plausible meth-
ods, but only 21% correct methods on average, conï¬rming that
tests cannot accurately establish the correctness of the generated
code.
RQ2 - Code Complexity. The four assistants generally generated
code with similar McCabe complexity to the code written by devel-
opers. In some cases, the generated code had slightly higher com-
plexity due to the use of explicit if conditions, or lower complexity
due to the use of lambda expressions and methods that encapsu-
late checks. Overall, the generated code was of similar complexity
to the original. The four tools did not diï¬€er signiï¬cantly in terms
of the complexity of the generated code.
RQ3 - Code Eï¬ƒciency. The four assistants generated code that
is as eï¬ƒcient as, or more eï¬ƒcient than, the code written by de-
velopers. A signiï¬cant portion of the generated methods, 87% for
ChatGTP and 100% for Tabnine, exhibited no signiï¬cant diï¬€erence
in execution time compared to the original methods. In some cases,
the generated code even outperformed the original code. The ex-
ceptions were Copilot and ChatGPT, which generated a small num-
ber of methods that were slower than the original ones. These inef-
ï¬ciencies were attributed to suboptimal data type choices, unnec-
essary operations, ineï¬ƒcient control ï¬‚ow, and redundant method
calls.
RQ4 - Code Size. We compared the number of lines of code (LOCs)
in the generated code and the code written by the developers for
all the methods in our dataset. The results show that the size of
the generated and original code is similar and that the four code
generation tools tend to generate code of similar length. ChatGPT
and Bard produced code with the highest diï¬€erence and variance
in length compared to the length of the code written by developers.
RQ5 - Code Similarity. The four assistants produced code that
is signiï¬cantly diï¬€erent from the code written by the developers,
with similarity measured according to the normalized Levenshtein
similarity [7] and CodeBLEU scores [5]. For the incorrectly gener-
ated code, the distances from the developersâ€™ code are larger than
the correct code. Tabnine generated the correct code that is most
similar to the developersâ€™ code (median CodeBLEU of 0.528).

This result suggests that although the generated code could be
close to the intended code in complexity and size, it still has to be
signiï¬cantly adjusted to fully match the expected implementation.

The results indicate that AI-based code assistants can be a valu-
able tool for developers, but they also need to be improved. While

Assessing AI-Based Code Assistants in Method Generation Tasks

ICSE-Companion â€™24, April 14â€“20, 2024, Lisbon, Portugal

[9] Priyan Vaithilingam, Tianyi Zhang, and Elena L. Glassman. 2022. Expectation
vs. Experience: Evaluating the Usability of Code Generation Tools Powered by
Large Language Models. In Extended Abstracts of the Conference on Human Fac-
tors in Computing Systems.

[10] Burak Yetistiren, Isik Ozsoy, and Eray Tuzun. 2022. Assessing the Quality of
GitHub Copilot?s Code Generation. In Proceedings of the International Conference
on Predictive Models and Data Analytics in Software Engineering.

PREMIER-TACO IS A FEW-SHOT POLICY LEARNER:
PRETRAINING MULTITASK REPRESENTATION VIA TEMPORAL
ACTION-DRIVEN CONTRASTIVE LOSS

A PREPRINT

Ruijie Zheng1âˆ—
Shuang Ma3

Yongyuan Liang1

Hal DaumÂ´e III1, 3

Xiyao Wang 1
Huazhe Xu2

John Langford3

Praveen Palanisamy3

Kalyan Shankar Basu3

Furong Huang1

1 University of Maryland, College Park 2 Tsinghua University
3 Microsoft Research
rzheng12@umd.edu

ABSTRACT

We present Premier-TACO, a multitask feature representation learning approach designed to improve
few-shot policy learning efficiency in sequential decision-making tasks. Premier-TACO leverages a
subset of multitask offline datasets for pretraining a general feature representation, which captures
critical environmental dynamics and is fine-tuned using minimal expert demonstrations. It advances
the temporal action contrastive learning (TACO) objective, known for state-of-the-art results in
visual control tasks, by incorporating a novel negative example sampling strategy. This strategy
is crucial in significantly boosting TACOâ€™s computational efficiency, making large-scale multitask
offline pretraining feasible. Our extensive empirical evaluation in a diverse set of continuous control
benchmarks including Deepmind Control Suite, MetaWorld, and LIBERO demonstrate Premier-
TACOâ€™s effectiveness in pretraining visual representations, significantly enhancing few-shot imitation
learning of novel tasks. Our code, pretraining data, as well as pretrained model checkpoints will be
released at https://github.com/PremierTACO/premier-taco.

1

Introduction

In the dynamic and ever-changing world we inhabit, the importance of sequential decision-making (SDM) in machine
learning cannot be overstated. Unlike static tasks, sequential decisions reflect the fluidity of real-world scenarios, from
robotic manipulations to evolving healthcare treatments. Just as foundation models in language, such as BERT (Devlin
et al., 2019) and GPT (Radford et al., 2019; Brown et al., 2020), have revolutionized natural language processing by
leveraging vast amounts of textual data to understand linguistic nuances, pretrained foundation models hold similar
promise for sequential decision-making (SDM). In language, these models capture the essence of syntax, semantics,
and context, serving as a robust starting point for a myriad of downstream tasks. Analogously, in SDM, where decisions
are influenced by a complex interplay of past actions, current states, and future possibilities, a pretrained foundation
model can provide a rich, generalized understanding of decision sequences. This foundational knowledge, built upon
diverse decision-making scenarios, can then be fine-tuned to specific tasks, much like how language models are adapted
to specific linguistic tasks.

The following challenges are unique to sequential decision-making, setting it apart from existing vision and language
pretraining paradigms. (C1) Data Distribution Shift: Training data usually consists of specific behavior-policy-
generated trajectories. This leads to vastly different data distributions at various stagesâ€”pretraining, finetuning, and
deploymentâ€”resulting in compromised performance (Lee et al., 2021). (C2) Task Heterogeneity: Unlike language
and vision tasks, which often share semantic features, decision-making tasks vary widely in configurations, transition
dynamics, and state and action spaces. This makes it difficult to develop a universally applicable representation. (C3)
Data Quality and Supervision: Effective representation learning often relies on high-quality data and expert guidance.

âˆ—The work is partially done during Ruijie Zhengâ€™s internship at Microsoft Research.

 
 
 
 
 
 
Premier-TACO: Pretraining Multitask Representation via Temporal Action-Driven Contrastive Loss

Figure 1: Performance of Premier-TACO pretrained visual representation for few-shot imitation learning on downstream unseen
